May 9, 1999: Fiction
WE'LL MEET AGAIN, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A woman
struggles to free herself of the suspicion that she murdered her husband.
THE GIRL WHO LOVED TOM GORDON, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $16.95.)
When a young girl gets lost in the woods, she is saved by her spiritual association
with a relief pitcher for the Boston Red Sox.
A NEW SONG, by Jan Karon. (Viking, $24.95.) A clergyman and his wife move
600 miles from home, creating new friendships and maintaining old ones.
BITTERSWEET, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) A woman copes with a
midlife crisis: should she continue to raise a family or should she pursue her old
career?
THE TESTAMENT, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A reclusive billionaire,
a burned-out lawyer and a missionary are brought together by a startling secret.
EAST OF THE MOUNTAINS, by David Guterson. (Harcourt Brace, $25.) A man
with cancer returns to the eastern Washington of his youth to commit suicide.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school of
witchcraft.
TARA ROAD, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $24.95.) Two women -- one from
Ireland, one from New England -- exchange houses for the summer.
VITTORIO, THE VAMPIRE, by Anne Rice. (Knopf, $19.95.) A supernatural siren
exercises her wiles in Renaissance Italy and seduces a teen-age boy.
SOUL OF THE FIRE, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Doherty, $27.95.) In Volume 5 of
the "Sword of Truth" fantasy series, a magical force threatens the land of D'Hara.
ABIDE WITH ME, by E. Lynn Harris. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The friendships and
sexual relationships of young people whose careers are beginning to blossom.
WHAT'S HEAVEN? by Maria Shriver. Illustrated by Sandra Speidel. (Golden
Books/St. Martin's, $15.) Kate's great-grandmother dies, and her mother consoles
her.
THE POISONWOOD BIBLE, by Barbara Kingsolver. (Harper Flamingo, $26.) Five
female characters narrate this novel set in the Belgian Congo.
THE GROUND BENEATH HER FEET, by Salman Rushdie. (Holt, $27.50.) From
Bombay to London to New York: an updated version of the Orpheus myth, set in
the glittering world of rock-and-roll celebrities.
Non-Fiction
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
ALL TOO HUMAN, by George Stephanopoulos. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) The
former adviser to President Clinton recalls his years in the White House.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A sportswriter
tells of his weekly visits to his old college mentor, who was near death's door.
BELLA TUSCANY, by Frances Mayes. (Broadway, $25.) An American writer
remembers a spring and summer spent in the romantic sections of Italy.
YESTERDAY, I CRIED, by Iyanla Vanzant. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A counselor
recalls how she turned painful experiences into feelings of hope.
THE CENTURY, by Peter Jennings and Todd Brewster. (Doubleday, $60.) An
account of the 20th century.
THE MAJORS, by John Feinstein. (Little, Brown, $25.) A journalist reports on the
1998 Masters, U.S. Open, British Open and P.G.A. golf tournaments.
BUSINESS @ THE SPEED OF THOUGHT, by Bill Gates with Collins Hemingway.
(Warner, $30.) How new technology is changing the ways business is done.
BLACK HAWK DOWN, by Mark Bowden. (Atlantic Monthly, $24.) The bloody
battle between American forces and Somali street fighters in Mogadishu in 1993.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
UNCOVERING CLINTON, by Michael Isikoff. (Crown, $25.) A journalist's account
of scandals in the Clinton White House and his role in reporting them.
TRAVELING MERCIES, by Anne Lamott. (Pantheon, $23.) A chronicle of the
author's journey toward faith.
THE LEXUS AND THE OLIVE TREE, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus &
Giroux, $27.50.) A journalist explains the instant electronic global economy.
THE ENDURANCE, by Caroline Alexander. (Knopf, $29.95.) The story of Ernest
Shackleton's 1914 Antarctic expedition.
WOMAN, by Natalie Angier. (Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A reporter examines
female biology and its effects on health, personal psychology and relationships.
